conclusion: On a v–t diagram the acceleration a(t) is the slope (tangent) of the curve at each instant.

In both curves (A and B) the tangent at t = 0 is steep and positive, then becomes progressively less steep, is zero at the peak velocity, and finally becomes negative as the curve slopes downward back to v = 0 at t = t₁.

premise: The slope of the curve represents acceleration.
conclusion: Hence the slope—and therefore the acceleration—steadily decreases from a positive value, passes through zero, and becomes negative.

premise: The slope of the curve represents acceleration.
conclusion: At no stage does the slope increase before it decreases.

premise: The slope of the curve represents acceleration.
conclusion: No. For both objects the acceleration continually decreases (from positive to zero to negative); it is not “first increasing and then decreasing.”
